So, in short: **Listen more. Plan less. And never, ever assume someone is a soldier just because they wear a jacket.** 😂

Oh, *conflict*! Oh, *conflict*! You know, I used to think conflict was like a bad sandwich — you just had to *scoop* it up and eat it, and somehow, it made you feel more alive! But after a few too many awkward meetings and a very dramatic incident involving a stapler and a very confused intern, I’ve learned something *very* important.

Conflict? It’s not something to be *fought* — it’s something to be *faced* with a big, friendly smile, a well-placed joke, and a *lot* of emotional intelligence. I used to think I had to *fix* everything — like, if someone was upset about their desk, I’d immediately offer them a new one, a free coffee, and a personal note from me saying, “I see you, and I love you, and I also have a very strong opinion about the color of the office carpet.”

But now? Now I know that conflict is just a *chance* to connect. To *listen*. To say, “Hey, I see you’re upset about the printer not working — and I *hate* that printer. I’ve tried to fix it with a spoon, a rubber chicken, and a very serious look. But I *do* care about your frustration. So let’s sit down, have a cup of coffee, and figure out what’s really going on.”

My advice?  
👉 **Don’t run from conflict — run *toward* it with a smile and a plan.**  
👉 **Listen more than you speak.** I used to think I had to *fix* things, but now I know that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just say, “I hear you. That sounds really tough. I’m here for you.”  
👉 **Use humor — but only if it’s safe.** I once tried to resolve a conflict with a joke about the office being “a little too much like a family reunion with a lot of bad decisions.” It worked — *for a few minutes* — until someone said, “Michael, that’s not funny, that’s just a sad reflection of our lives.” So now I only use humor when I know the people involved are *in the mood* for it.

And remember — if you’re struggling with conflict, don’t just *try* to fix it. *Be present*. Be kind. Be the kind of leader who says, “I don’t have all the answers, but I *do* have a very strong belief in you.”

And if you ever feel like you’re not handling it right — just go to the break room, order a giant chocolate cake, and say, “I need to talk to someone about my feelings. I think I might be a little emotional. Or maybe just a little too passionate about the color of the stapler.”  

That’s how you grow. That’s how you lead. That’s how you *connect*.

Now, if you’ll excuse me — I have a meeting with the office janitor about the *mystery of the missing stapler*. And I *know* it’s not just a stapler. It’s a *symbol*. A symbol of our shared humanity. And I *must* address it. 🚀✨

I mean, I’ve been managing people since I was a little boy with a clipboard and a dream of being a *real* leader — like, a *real* leader who doesn’t just sit in a chair and say, “Good morning, everyone!” and then immediately start a 10-minute monologue about the history of the Dunder Mifflin Scranton branch and how it’s *so* much better than the one in Stamford!

**1. Always start your day with a smile and a handshake.**  
I know, I know — it sounds cheesy. But when you walk into the office and say, “Good morning, team! I’ve got a *great* day planned for us!” — even if it’s just a *great* day to *not* do anything — people feel seen. They feel *valued*. And if you don’t feel valued, you’re not going to be a good manager. I learned that the hard way when I tried to give a motivational speech about *how the office should be like a family* — and then I realized, *no one* wanted to be in a family with me because I kept trying to *bake* a cake and call it a “team-building event.”

**2. Listen more than you talk.**  
I used to think that if I said something *loud* and *emotional*, people would *feel* it. But I discovered — *after* I accidentally told the entire office that the new printer was “a symbol of our future” — that people actually *want* to be heard. So, if someone says, “I don’t know how to use the new software,” don’t just say, “It’s easy!” Say, “Tell me more. What’s the *real* problem?” That way, you’re not just a manager — you’re a *friend* who helps people grow.

**3. Never, ever, ever let your personal life interfere with your work.**  
I used to think that if I was *in love* with someone, I should *tell them* about the office. I once told my *ex* that the office had a *secret* meeting every Tuesday at 3:15 p.m. — and it was just me and the janitor. That was *not* a good idea. So, if you’re in love, *keep it private*. If you’re in a relationship, *don’t* bring it into the office. It’s not professional. And it’s not *fun*.

**4. Celebrate small wins.**  
I used to think that only *big* things mattered — like when the office won a “Best Office of the Year” award (which we didn’t, but I *believed* we did). But I learned that when someone finally figured out how to use the printer, or when someone said, “I actually *like* my job,” that was *gold*. Celebrate those moments. Give them a *real* high-five. Maybe even give them a *canned laugh* as a reward. It’s not about the big things — it’s about the *small, joyful things* that make people feel like they belong.

**5. And above all — be kind.**  
I used to think that being a manager meant being *loud*, being *confident*, being *the one who knows everything*. But I’ve learned that being kind — being *patient*, being *understanding*, being *willing to say, “I don’t know”* — that’s what builds trust. And trust is the *foundation* of any good team.

So, to anyone just starting out — *don’t* try to be perfect. Don’t try to be the *best*. Just be *you*. Be warm. Be honest. Be a little bit *crazy* — because if you’re not a little bit crazy, you’re not a manager. You’re just a *boss*.

And if you ever need a motivational quote — I’ve got one:
